body:
Without having looked at the source code, it seems that **only if `-` is followed by an (English) letter or `_` (notably, not a _digit_) is it interpreted as a parameter name**.

The following calls succeed, because the `-<char>` sequences are _not_ treated as parameter names (and therefore _positionally_ bind to `-bar`):

```powershell
function foo { [CmdletBinding()]param($bar) "[$bar]" }
[char[]] '~`!@#$%^*+0<>./\[]' | % { iex "foo -$_" }
```

Note that while `` ` `` works in principle, it retains its escaping function, so something like ``-`a`` rings the bell, and `` -`n `` passes `-<newline>`.

[_Update_, based on your comment] Similarly, `$` is used as-is  by itself (`-$`) or if followed by a character not valid in a variable name (`-$@`); `$(...)` (`-$('hi')`) and `$<identifier>` (`-$HOME`) are treated as subexpressions / variable references, possibly followed by other literal chars / `$` constructs.

(Perhaps surprisingly, given that `@` and `$` work), `{` / `}` and `(` / `)` don't work.

Neither do the quoting chars., `"` and `'`.

As you state, `-` doesn't work (`--` makes the binder treat all remaining tokens as _positional_ arguments, so that
`foo -- -unknownswitch` works, for instance).

Non-prefix metacharacters `,`, `;`, `|`, and `&` still have their usual meaning and also cannot be used.

`-?` is intercepted and always shows help.

---

As an aside: Using `-%`, to form `--%`, the stop parsing symbol, is recognized as such even with additional characters immediately following it, because its special treatment of the remaining command line kicks in _instantly_.

Curiously, it breaks the invocation altogether, because no arguments are then recognized anymore (granted, `--%` is for _external programs_, but the behavior is still curious):

```powershell
# Without --%, these would succeed.
foo --% a # fails
foo --% -bar baz # fails
```

Another `--%` problem: #11608

I'm not sure if the behavior is by design or by accident. If it is right, and even if it is wrong if people depend on it . It certainly feels wrong to me but I'm not sure I should be judging. 

`->x.txt `
is another odd one. Is it ever _meant_ or only ever a typo for >x.txt

I hope someone else can speak to that; my intent was simply to document the current behavior, which definitely has quirks and is hard to predict.
